title: Astros fans grapple with 'tasteless' remark, specter of domestic violence
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: USA TODAY Sports' Nancy Armour provides her opinion on the controversial situation surrounding the Houston Astros and executive Brandon Taubman. USA TODAY

HOUSTON – In his year and a half as a Houston Astro, Roberto Osuna has been a capable if unremarkable closer, saving 38 games this year and 50 overall, a useful cog on a team of superstars and MVPs.

And then a high-ranking club official had to remind the fan base that while Osuna has done all the Astros have asked, the franchise still has a long way to go in comprehending domestic violence.

Assistant general manager Brandon Taubman’s expletive-filled tirade directed at female reporters in the wake of the Astros’ pennant-winning victory in the American League Championship Series was framed as a defense of the closer, but instead unintentionally highlighted the fact Osuna served a 75-game suspension last season after he allegedly assaulted the mother of his then-three-year-old child.

The Astros’ response – clumsy at best, toxic at worst – managed to keep the story in public view all the way up to Tuesday night’s Game 1 of the World Series, nearly three nights after Osuna blew the Game 6 ALCS save that apparently fueled Taubman’s tirade.

For Astros fans, Osuna’s past transgressions and Taubman’s outburst haven’t quite created a moral dilemma. The event has, however, forced many to dig deep for a sentiment landing somewhere on the spectrum between tolerance and forgiveness.

“I’m not judging the man,” Shelly Bordonaro, a 57-year-old fan from Port Arthur said of Taubman. "I’m just saying what he said was tasteless. We all make mistakes.

“But you have to be careful what you say.”

Of a dozen-plus Astros fans queried before Game 1, none indicated their enjoyment of a second championship in three years would be in any way dulled by Osuna being at the bottom of a celebratory pile after recording the final out.

They minced few words regarding Taubman.

“There’s so many good people on the Astros,” says Rebel Prestwood, who commuted from Bridge City for the game. “That’s not necessarily a reflection on the team.”

Lora Liberty, a 35-year-old from The Woodlands, played softball collegiately and said compartmentalizing Osuna’s past was “not about the player; it’s about the team. I’ve played softball my whole life, and I know what it’s like to be a team player.”

The hundreds of jerseys and shirseys hugging the backs of fans filing through the concourse represented a diverse cross-section of their heroes: Correa, Springer, Bregman, Altuve – so many Altuves – along with newer, shinier models touting relative newcomers Michael Brantley and Yordan Alvarez.

Over a 90-minute period, there were no Osunas to be found, perhaps a reflection that the fan base merely tolerates, but does not celebrate, their closer.
description: The Astros’ response managed to keep the story in public view all the way up to Tuesday night’s Game 1 of the World Series.
